entry.title: Expose SAP CPI Integration Flows as APIs Using SAP API Management: A Step-by-Step Guide
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP Integration Suite empowers businesses to integrate applications and processes efficiently. One powerful capability is exposing CPI integration flows as APIs via API Management (APIM). This enables centralized governance, security, and monitoring of APIs. In this blog, we’ll cover the step-by-step process to achieve this.

Step 1: Set Up SAP Process Integration Runtime

Navigate to SAP BTP Cockpit → Subaccount → Instances & Subscriptions.

  • Create Service Instance
    • Service: SAP Process Integration Runtime
    • Plan: api
    • Instance Name: e.g. CPI_API_Instance
    • Assign all roles (except security roles)Create Service Key

      Click the ⋮ (three-dot menu) → Create Service Key → Save credentials (Client ID, Client Secret, Token URL).

Step 2: Design & Deploy a Sample iFlow

In Integration Suite:

  • Create Package:
    Navigate to Design → Integrations & APIs → Create Package (e.g. Demo_API_Package).

  • Build iFlow:
    Add an HTTP Sender and a Content Modifier (set sample body content).
    Deploy the iFlow.

 

 

 

Step 3: Configure API Provider with OAuth2

In API Management:

  • Create API Provider:
    Navigate to Configure → API Providers → Create New.
    • Name: CPI_Provider
    • Connection Type: Cloud Integration
    • Host: Use host from Service Key
    • Authentication: OAuth2 Client Credentials
      • Enter Client ID, Client Secret, Token URL

 

Step 4: Create & Deploy API Proxy

  • Create API Proxy:
    Select the API Provider → Click Discover → Choose deployed iFlow.
    Enable OAuth and provide credentials.
    • Proxy Name: flow-api-proxy
    • Save & Deploy.

 

Step 5: Test Your API

Use Postman:

  • Paste the Proxy URL
  • Send a request
  • Confirm the response from your iFlow.

 

Conclusion

By exposing SAP CPI integration flows as managed APIs through SAP API Management, you create a robust integration layer that blends flexibility with strong governance. This approach offers several key benefits:

  • Centralized Control: Manage all APIs from a single platform, making lifecycle management simple and efficient.
  • Enhanced Security: Protect your integrations with OAuth2 and other security policies to prevent unauthorized access.
  • Scalability & Reusability: Reuse APIs across multiple applications and business processes, cutting down development time and effort.
  • Comprehensive Monitoring: Gain full visibility into API performance and usage with built-in analytics and dashboards.

This setup not only streamlines integration but also supports modern API-driven architectures, enabling faster innovation and better interoperability across your enterprise. As a next step, consider adding features like rate limiting, caching, and custom policies in API Management to further boost performance and security.

entry.title: The Art of Possible: Why Now Is the Time for SAP Sales and Service AI Agents in Customer Experience
entry.content:
Estimated reading time ≈ 9–10 minutes

1. Why AI Agents in CX Now?

The timing for AI agents in customer experience couldn’t be better. We’ve reached the point where rising customer expectations, the need for rapid decisions, the demand for scalable personalization, and the evolution of AI have all converged.

Together, they’re transforming how sales and service teams deliver value—and how customers experience every interaction.

Rising Customer Expectations Are Raising the Stakes

Today’s customers expect instant, effortless experiences across every touchpoint. And when they don’t get them, they leave.

  • 59% of customers abandon a brand after two negative service experiences
  • 76% of customers expect companies to understand their needs and preferences.
  • 57% of customers prefer engaging with automated systems for simple inquiries. (Source)

Traditional customer service models can’t keep up with this level of demand. AI agents can—by responding instantly, understanding customer intent, and routing issues to the right place the first time.

The Speed of Business Demands Faster Decisions

Business moves at lightning speed, and slow responses can cost revenue and reputation.

AI agents excel in fast-moving environments. They can read and process unstructured data—like emails, chat logs, and support tickets—and turn it into actionable insights in seconds.

While human agents need time to research and analyse, AI agents can instantly access customer history, identify patterns, and make data-driven decisions in real time.

Scalable Personalization Is No Longer Optional

Customers want more than good service—they want service that feels personal. But delivering that at scale is beyond what traditional systems can do.

With Generative AI, personalization becomes effortless. AI agents can analyse massive datasets to create tailored recommendations, custom messages, and proactive support for every individual—across every channel, and without adding headcount.

AI Is the New Assistant for Sales & Service Teams

We’ve moved far beyond basic chatbots. Today’s AI agents act as intelligent assistants, transforming how teams work and how customers interact.

They can:

  • Streamline daily operations
  • Handle complex transactions (like billing or payment extensions)
  • Maintain accuracy and compliance
  • Work 24/7, without fatigue

For human teams, that means less manual effort and more time focused on building relationships and solving complex problems that require empathy and creativity.

The Bottom Line

AI agents are no longer a futuristic idea—they’re a business necessity.

They bring together speed, personalization, and intelligence to deliver exceptional customer experiences at scale.

The question isn’t if your organization should embrace AI agents. It’s how quickly you can start.

 

2. What is the SAP CX AI Toolkit?

The SAP CX AI Toolkit brings together embedded generative and predictive AI to deliver intelligent automation and smarter customer experiences. This cloud-native solution integrates directly into SAP CX systems, enabling businesses to automate case categorization, inquiry routing, and unstructured data processing for faster, more accurate outcomes.

Generative AI personalizes content, summaries, and recommendations, while predictive AI anticipates customer behaviour to drive proactive engagement. With capabilities like visual search, AI-powered product tagging, and role-specific insights across Sales, Service, Commerce, and the Customer Data Platform, the toolkit connects data and intelligence to create seamless, personalized interactions at every touchpoint.

 

3. The Agent Concept — From Tasks to Outcomes?

The CX AI Toolkit represents a fundamental shift from traditional AI that merely suggests to intelligent agents that execute, automate, and guide across complete business processes in both Sales & Service V1 and V2 environments.

Agents That Execute Real Actions

Unlike conventional AI tools that provide recommendations requiring human action, CX AI agents directly execute business processes. When a customer service ticket arrives, the Classification Agent handles smart categorization and instant routing based on business rules - it doesn't just suggest a category, it automatically assigns it and routes the case to the appropriate team. The Knowledge Agent not only documents the solution but intelligently captures customer needs and usage patterns, creating structured knowledge articles and publishing them directly to your knowledge base.

Comprehensive Process Automation

These agents work together to automate complex repetitive tasks with contextual understanding. The Q&A Agent automatically searches the knowledge base and matches solutions, while simultaneously providing immediate answers to product or upgrade questions. This creates a seamless flow where AI agents can process large volumes of data to identify patterns and trends that might be overlooked by human analysis, enabling end-to-end automation rather than isolated task assistance.

Intelligent Guidance Across V1 and V2 Environments

The toolkit adapts its guidance capabilities based on the specific SAP environment:

Sales & Service Cloud V2 supports comprehensive contextual behaviours where agents work by matching the tool to the entity in focus. When you open a Service Case, the AI Tool will read the case that is currently open and will pre-fill that case for you in the AI Tool. The system maintains awareness of your workflow, with recently viewed cases appearing as suggestions during searches.

Sales Cloud V1 offers additional capabilities like the Quote Creation Agent, though this functionality is confirmed to be supported only for Sales Cloud V1 and there is no confirmed roadmap for support in Sales Cloud V2.

Process-Wide Intelligence

What sets these agents apart is their ability to maintain all the context and customer intelligence throughout the journey, while automating the time-consuming tasks. They don't just execute individual steps - they orchestrate entire workflows. For example, when a service case is resolved, the same intelligence that helped with classification and resolution now provides immediate answers to any product or upgrade questions included in the opportunity notes, ensuring no context is lost in handoffs between teams.

Ready-to-Deploy Automation

These agents are delivered through the CX AI Toolkit and work out of the box with SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud, requiring no custom development. Organizations can configure specialized AI agents that perform complex business tasks with no coding required, achieving 50% higher service staff productivity for agent-handled tasks and 50% productivity boost in service teams .

The CX AI Toolkit transforms AI from a suggestion engine into an active participant in your business processes, executing tasks, automating workflows, and providing intelligent guidance that adapts to your specific SAP environment and business context.

 

4. Key Agents for Sales and Service Cloud

Agents suitable for both of Sales and Service Cloud

Q&A Agent

The Q&A Agent processes natural language questions and delivers accurate responses by searching knowledge bases and matching solutions. Key capabilities include:

  • Processes natural language questions and delivers accurate responses
  • Allows administrators to define specific questions answered using custom data sources, tickets, or cases
  • Provides 50% higher sales staff productivity for agent-handled tasks
  • Instant access to the most experienced agent's knowledge
  • Works with both Sales / Service Cloud V1 and V2

Knowledge Creation Agent

The Knowledge Creation Agent analyses new tickets or cases and automatically creates Knowledge Base Articles (KBA) that are published back to the source. Key capabilities include:

  • Analyses new tickets or cases and creates Knowledge Base Articles (KBA)
  • Publishes articles back to the source ticket or case
  • Increases sales staff productivity by focusing on high-value customer interactions 
  • Intelligent documentation of solutions and customer usage patterns
  • Increased focus on high-value customer interactions
  • Improved customer satisfaction through better knowledge capture
  • 50% higher service staff productivity for agent-handled tasks

Sales Cloud Agent

Quote Creation Agent  

The Quote Creation Agent is designed to streamline the quote generation process. Key capabilities include:

  • Automates quote generation by monitoring Microsoft Office 365 shared mailboxes
  • Transforms incoming email requests into ready-to-send quotes
  • Increases sales efficiency and drives revenue growth by eliminating manual, repetitive work
  • Important limitation: Currently supported only for Sales Cloud V1, with no confirmed roadmap for Sales Cloud V2 support

Service Cloud Agent

Case Classification Agent

The Case Classification Agent analyses new customer service tickets and automatically classifies them based on company business requirements. This agent provides:

  • Smart categorization and instant routing based on business rules
  • Elimination of manual classification work that typically consumes valuable agent time
  • 50% higher service staff productivity for agent-handled tasks
  • Greater operational performance across service processes

5. The “Art of Possible”: From Classification to Knowledge Creation

It’s 3 PM on a Friday afternoon at MedTech Solutions, and Dr. Martinez, a senior support specialist, receives a new support ticket:

“Our new imaging software keeps freezing during patient scans, causing delays in our radiology department. We’ve tried restarting, but the issue persists during high-resolution scans.”

For most teams, this would mark the start of a long weekend challenge—manual triage, frantic back-and-forths, and lost time. This is where our AI Agents step into action.

The Classification Agent in Action

Within seconds, the Classification Agent gets to work. It scans the ticket, picking up on terms like “imaging software,” “freezing,” “patient scans,” and “radiology.”

Instead of waiting for a human to assign it, the AI instantly tags it as a Critical Software Issue and routes it directly to the Medical Software Support team with Priority 1 status.

No delays. No confusion. Just precision routing—powered by AI that understands the business context and works 24/7 like a digital triage expert.

The Intelligent Handoff

The ticket appears in Dr. Martinez’s queue, already enriched with context and suggested similar cases. The system’s recommendations immediately point her toward a known pattern—high-resolution scans causing memory strain.

With insights at her fingertips, she diagnoses the problem as a memory allocation issue and resolves it by fine-tuning the software’s buffer settings. The radiology department is back online in minutes, not hours.

The Knowledge Creation Agent Steps In

As Dr. Martinez documents her fix, the Knowledge Creation Agent automatically analyses the resolution details. Recognizing a recurring pattern, it generates a new Knowledge Base Article (KBA) titled:

“Resolving Memory Allocation Issues in High-Resolution Medical Imaging Software.”

The article is structured, formatted, and published—ready for future reference by both customers and support teams.

What once required hours of manual work—classification, resolution, documentation—has now become a continuous learning loop powered by intelligent automation.

The Art of Possible

In this single interaction, the CX AI Toolkit transformed a complex support challenge into a self-improving process:

  • The Classification Agent ensured the ticket reached the right expert immediately.
  • The Knowledge Creation Agent turned the solution into reusable knowledge.
  • And Dr. Martinez? She focused on solving problems, not managing workflows.

This is the Art of the Possible—where AI doesn’t just assist but learns, acts, and teaches, creating a smarter, faster, and more connected customer experience.

To explore the Art of possible in real life, check out one of our favourite customer stories from Bosch and see how AI is optimizing business and boosting efficiency.


 

6. Architecture

In the following diagram discover our architecture in which all of enterprise data is flowing from different data sources (SAP, Microsoft or Custom ones) into a secure foundation (more details in the section 7. Governance & Trust). AI Services transform this data into intelligence through search, reasoning and orchestration. This intelligence powers the CX AI Toolkit, where tools for content creation, Q&A, intelligent search, and even custom AI agents come together.

Finally, these capabilities appear wherever teams work—inside the web application, a Chrome extension, or fully embedded experiences—bringing AI directly into every sales and service moment.

 

7. Governance & Trust

 The SAP CX AI Toolkit operates through a six-step Trusted AI Layer that ensures secure and ethical AI processing:

  1. Secure Data Retrieval: Adheres to SAP's best practices, ensuring only relevant data is accessible through user credentials when pulling information from connected systems
  2. SAP Context Grounding: Utilizes Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) concepts to enrich GenAI prompts with comprehensive ancillary information surrounding data objects to enhance output quality
  3. Obfuscation and Bias Prevention: Implements robust obfuscation techniques, hashing all identifiable information and replacing it with temporary placeholders across all fields. This process also aids in bias prevention by filtering out sensitive attributes like gender or nationality
  4. Zero Data Retention: Ensures all data transmitted to LLM services is securely deleted after each transaction, significantly reducing the risk of proprietary data exposure
  5. Audit Logs: Maintains rigorous audit logs aligned with SAP guidelines, providing Trace IDs for error tracking
  6. Human in the Loop: Emphasizes preventing automatic data dissemination without validation, acknowledging that GenAI outputs require human oversight

SAP ensures transparency through:

  • Documentation and UI Indicators: Clear marking of AI systems and effective communication of their capabilities and limitations
  • Post-hoc Explanation Tools: Implementation of tools like SHAP and LIME for explainable AI
  • Traceable Systems: All AI systems must be traceable and transparent in their operations

Users maintain full transparency and control over their data through:

  • Centralized Dashboard: Full transparency and control over data through a central dashboard
  • Anonymized Data Processing: Customer data combines accuracy with uncompromised security through anonymization
  • No Third-Party Training: SAP does not share customer data with external vendors for model training

Governance Structure

SAP's responsible AI implementation includes:

  • Global AI Ethics Steering Committee: Senior SAP leaders reviewing approach, processes, and product capabilities
  • AI Ethics Advisory Panel: Additional governance body ensuring ethical compliance
  • Regular Review Processes: Continuous evaluation and updates of ethical guidelines

SAP's approach to responsible AI is built on a comprehensive framework that ensures ethical, secure, and compliant AI development and deployment across all business applications. The company has established itself as a leader in responsible AI practices through rigorous governance structures and adherence to international standards.

 

8. How to Get Started

To start with AI Toolkit, it’s necessary to set clearly defined and measurable objectives for AI agent implementation, while prioritizing Data Quality.

Find about how you can start with the implementation and get use of Multi-Model Support Architecture here: Setting Up your SAP CX AI Toolkit System | SAP Help Portal

Helpful assets: 

  • Discovery Center - AI Capabilities
  • Discovery Center - AI Estimator
  • SAP CX AI Toolkit | SAP Help Portal
  • See How AI Agents Streamline Customer Service

In the SAP Road Map Explorer you can find out what is planned for future releases of the AI Toolkit, but also what we have already upgraded in the past. 

If you would like to check what is coming to Agentic technology in Sales Cloud V2, we suggest you, visit Unleashing Agentic AI in SAP Sales Cloud V2 : Her... - SAP Community

 

9. Partnership between Humans and AI Agents

The art of the possible with AI agents in sales and service isn't just about what technology can do—it's about what humans and AI can achieve together as partners. AI Agents are ideal partners for use cases that are mentioned in the article because the time used to train and prepare is insignificant compared to time and cost savings they deliver over time.

What is important to always have on your mind? AI Agents will always need human guidance to understand urgency from customer or to sense need for different kind of assistance, no matter how much we train them. This is why humans need to master AI Mastermind and unlock the full potential of this partnership!

entry.title: "No authorized user found" for Open Connector
entry.content:
Hello together.

I´m doing the tutorial "Establish Connection Between Your BambooHR Trial and Open Connectors" ( https://developers.sap.com/tutorials/btp-integration-suite-nonsapconnectivity-openconnectors.html).

When I click "Discover Connectors" I got forwarded to a logon page. There I log on with my only user (which happens to be my sap universal id) and then get the following error message.

<message>No authorized user found. Please contact your administrator to obtain access. More details see SAP Note : https://me.sap.com/notes/3035458</message>

The SAP-Note that comes with the error message does not help. Since it is for users that did not activate the capabilty. But since I do only have one user, the user who activated the capabilty is the same as the one tries to open it.

Does anybody has any idea what I´m doing wrong?

 

Also the other blog entry about this topic "https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-q-a/open-connector-no-authorized-user-found/qaq-p/12793663" seems not to fit my problem. There is also quoted: "The person who has subscribed to the Integration Suite initially would have the admin access to the Open Connectors". But this is my user too, so again I should have acces with admin right, regarding this post.

 

Kind regards

 Patrick

entry.title: Serial Number Profile : Prefix (CBC activity 103636)
entry.content:
Hello,

I am trying to set up Serial number prefix for my customer.

I have read this blog which explains how to kind of manage serial numbers number range but this model can only work if we want to have the same number ranges for ALL materials in all divisions because the reange number is related to the equipment category. Also it will only accept digits, no alphanumerical characters, special character etc...

Instead, I thought about using the Prefix field in the CBC activity 103636 which really seems dedicated to that usage:

But whether it is numerical or alphanumerical characters, the prefix won't show on the material serial numbers automatically created.

Note : this is to work with WM.

Any idea what I am doing wrong to make it work?

Many thanks,

Adrien

entry.title: Reversing and Adjusting Depreciation and Net Book Value
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

We acquired an asset on 31 December 2024 with a useful life of one year. We have posted depreciation for the last ten months, but the audit team informed us that the asset was acquired with the wrong value and that part of the cost should go to an AUC.

How can we adjust the net book value of the original asset and reverse or adjust the posted ordinary and accumulated depreciation?

The original net book value was 1730970 and it should be 1442475.

The difference of 288495 should be transferred to the AUC.

The ordinary monthly depreciation posted was 144247 but it should have been 120206.

A total of 240410 should be reversed.

How can we adjust all these values correctly in the system?

entry.title: VOFM – Custom Routine for Packaging Instruction Determination in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, during packaging instruction determination for production receipts with synchronous posting, the system automatically determines the main packaging instruction. However, the alternative packaging instructions are not displayed.

In my case, the selection of an alternative instruction is based on the Production Version, but this field is not available in the field catalog for condition-based determination. In the configuration step Define Schema for Packaging Instruction Determination, there is a “Condition” field. In on-premise systems, this would be implemented using a condition formula created in transaction VOFM.

I have seen SAP Notes related to VOFM enablement in Cloud for sales pricing determination (for example, Note 2885513). I also checked the documentation here:
https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/32da8359c8ee4e8b8e8c5e15cacba5aa/e78cbf53f106b44ce10000000a174cb4.html?locale=en-US
but found nothing regarding packaging instruction determination.

My question is:
Is it possible to develop custom condition formulas for packaging instruction determination in SAP Public Cloud?
If yes, what is the correct approach?

Thanks in advance.

entry.title: SAP EHS Public Cloud: Extending Your Existing Landscape Side-by-Side - Guidebook (Part 2)
entry.content:
Integrating SAP EHS Public Cloud: Extending Your Existing Landscape Side-by-Side - Guidebook

Part 2: Integration of Employees from SAP SuccessFactors

Table of Contents:

  • 1. Why is this Integration required?
  • 2. Prerequisites
  • 3. Technical Integration
  • 3.1 SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central (EC) Configuration
  • 3.2 SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Configuration
  • 3.2.1 Communication User
  • 3.2.2 Communication System
  • 3.2.3 Communication Arrangement
  • 3.2.4 Monitoring of Replication Scenarios in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
  • 3.3 Integration Package Implementation in SAP Cloud Integration
  • 3.3.1 Integration Credentials Configuration
  • 3.3.2 Copying Integration Packages
  • 3.3.3 Integration Package Configuration
  • 3.3.4 Reset Existing Delta Sync Configuration
  • 3.4 End-to-End Monitoring of Employee Master Data Replication
  • 3.4.1 Monitoring Across Systems
  • 3.4.2 Monitoring in SAP Integration Suite
  • 4. Lessons Learned
  • 5. Engage with Us

Related Content:

Below is an overview of the planned blog series – each post focusing on a specific integration topic. Once published, the titles will be linked for direct access:

Integrating SAP EHS in the Public Cloud: Extending Your Existing Landscape Side-by-Side – Guidebook

Part 1: Introduction & OverviewLink
Part 2: Integration of Employees from SAP SuccessFactorsLink
Part 3: Integration of Business Partners & Material from SAP Master Data Governance (MDG)Link
Part 4: Integration of Functional Locations & Equipment from SAP S/4HANA On-Premise SystemLink
Part 5: Extensibility Scenarios & Further ImplementationLink
Part 6: Summary & OutlookLink

 

1. Why is this Integration required?

Integrating employee data from SAP SuccessFactors into SAP EHS Public Cloud is a foundational step for enabling core EHS processes such as Incident Management, Risk Management, and Emissions Management. Instead of maintaining employee data locally within SAP EHS Public Cloud, the system relies on Workforce Person master data replicated from the corporate HR system. This ensures that roles, organizational assignments, and reporting lines remain consistent across the enterprise.

Accurate and up-to-date employee data is essential in Environment, Health & Safety (EHS), as many process steps are people-driven – including incident reporting, assigning investigation responsibilities, approvals, and regulatory documentation. Moreover, EHS integrated workflow functionalities are heavily based on a role and responsibility concept, which depends on the correct assignment of persons within the organization.

In other words: Without employee integration, SAP EHS Public Cloud cannot correctly identify, assign, or document the people involved in an incident or are responsible for EHS tasks.

Architectural Approach - Scope

The highlighted section of the architectural diagram illustrates the scope relevant to this blog post - focusing on the integration of employees from SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central (EC) into SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Note: While this post focuses on the standard integration scenario using SAP SuccessFactors EC as the source, employee master data can also be replicated from other connected HR systems or SAP S/4HANA On-Premise / Private Cloud environments. In such cases, a customized integration flow can be implemented in SAP Integration Suite to transfer the workforce data into SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. If the integration to the relevant HR system already exists, this step can be skipped.

Reference to User Scenario (A) – Incident Management

In part 1 "Introduction & Overview”, the User Scenario (A) Incident Management at Mike Machineries (chapter 2.1.1) clearly demonstrated why this integration is required:

Scenario Step

Why Employee Integration Matters

An internal maintenance technician is injured

The injured person must be identified as an employee, with job role, organizational unit, and location stored to support injury documentation, reporting and regulatory requirements.

A colleague nearby reports the incident in the system

The system must recognize the reporter as an employee with the correct role and permission to create an incident entry.

A First Aider records medical details in the Injury/Illness Log Entry

EHS needs accurate employee data to identify the certified First Aider and capture their involvement for documentation and accountability.

The Incident Manager is automatically notified and assigned

The Incident Manager must be derived from organizational structures, supervisory relationships, or assigned safety roles maintained in HR.

Corrective and preventive actions are assigned to employees

Task ownership, due dates, approvals, and completion tracking require valid employee master data to ensure accountability and reporting across the organization.

Learnings are shared across sites with operations and safety teams

Up-to-date organizational structures ensure that communication reaches the right target audience for safety awareness and training measures.

Without integrated employee data, the system would not be able to:

  • Identify the injured person, reporter or First Aider,
  • Determine the responsible Incident Manager, or
  • Track assigned corrective actions across organizational units.

This makes the integration of employees from SAP SuccessFactors EC into SAP EHS Public Cloud a mandatory first step before configuring Incident Management.

Note: When implementing Incident Management as shown here in the user scenario, please ensure that scope item 3FP – Incident Management is activated in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud via Central Business Configuration (CBC) beforehand. This activation is required to enable the Incident Management processes and related configuration in SAP EHS Public Cloud.

While this integration is a prerequisite for Incident Management, it is equally relevant across other EHS use cases such as Risk Management or Emissions Management. In these scenarios, consistent employee master data provides the foundation for assigning roles and responsibilities, managing organizational structures, and ensuring accurate process execution and compliance. Therefore, in the following section, we will take a closer look at the general setup of the employee data integration between SAP SuccessFactors and SAP EHS Public Cloud.

 

2. Prerequisites

To successfully set up the integration scenario for SAP EHS Public Cloud, several prerequisites must be met. These prerequisites ensure that employee master data can be replicated from SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central (EC) to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud using the predefined integration scenario delivered with scope item JB1 – Maintain Employee Master Data.

Important: Activating scope item JB1 enables the required communication scenarios in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, allowing the predefined integration flows in SAP Integration Suite to securely exchange and replicate employee data between the two systems.

To successfully set up this integration scenario, the following prerequisites must be in place:

Tenant Provisioning:

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud tenant
  • SAP SuccessFactors EC tenant
  • SAP Cloud Integration tenant (SAP Integration Suite)

Certificate Setup:

  • Certificates are required only if certificate-based authentication is used for the connection (recommended for productive environments)
  • In our case, Basic Authentication was used for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, and OAuth 2.0 SAML Bearer Assertion for SAP SuccessFactors, which requires a Key Pair in the SAP Integration Suite instead of an X.509 certificate exchange.

Administrator Access: Admin users must be available across all three systems:

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud - The administrator should have the template role of SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR to allow creation of communication users, systems, and arrangements.
  • SAP SuccessFactors EC
  • SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) / SAP Integration Suite

Scope Item Activation:

  • Scope item "Core HR with SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central (JB1)" must be activated in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud system.

Data Requirements:

  • Legal entities in SAP SuccessFactors must match the Company Codes in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud (Mismatches will lead to replication failures).

Employee Import Restriction:

  • Once employees have been replicated from SAP SuccessFactors EC to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, do not manually create or upload the same employee (e.g., via Manage Workforce app). Mixing manually created records with replicated records can lead to data inconsistencies and replication conflicts.

 

3. Technical Integration

This section describes the practical implementation of the employee data integration based on the predefined JB1 – Core HR with SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central scope item. It outlines how workforce data is replicated from SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central (EC) to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and highlights the key configuration areas involved in the process.

The JB1 scope item provides the standard integration scenario for workforce data replication and supports related HR data flows relevant for Incident, Risk, and Emissions Management. Accurate and consistent employee master data is crucial for these EHS use cases, as incidents, responsibilities, and corrective actions depend on properly linked workforce information.

Therefore, this section focuses on the JB1 – Maintain Employee Master Data process, which serves as the foundation for all subsequent EHS configurations.

Key JB1 Configuration Areas:

  • SAP SuccessFactors EC Configuration
  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Configuration
  • Integration Package Setup in SAP Cloud Integration
  • Monitoring and Operations

For a detailed documentation, please refer to the official JB1 content in the SAP Process Navigator - SAP for Me.

How to find JB1 setup instructions as a PDF

To view the process visualization, open JB1 – 02 Maintain Employee Master Data in the SAP Process Navigator.

Select "Maintain Employee Master Data" process flow

 

"Maintain Employee Master Data" process flow

 3.1 SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central (EC) Configuration

To prepare SAP SuccessFactors EC for the employee master data replication to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, several configuration steps must be completed upfront. In our setup, SAP SuccessFactors was already fully implemented and configured, and our focus was primarily on enabling the integration with SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. Nevertheless, we have summarized the key configuration steps below to outline the main areas that typically need to be in place to support the JB1 replication scenario. For a detailed, step-by-step configuration, the official SAP Best Practice documentation can be referenced (JB1 setup instructions – chapter 3).

Provisioning Settings in EC

The configuration begins in SuccessFactors Provisioning, where core system settings must be enabled to support employee data replication. This includes activating EC core features, ensuring required language packs are available, and enabling the necessary integration add-ons and OData APIs. These provisioning settings form the technical foundation that allows EC to supply employee data to external systems, including SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Push Replication Setup (Optional but Recommended)

Employee data can be transferred to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud either through scheduled replication jobs or by using push replication. Push replication enables near-real-time updates and is recommended for scenarios where timely employee data is needed, such as EHS processes. If enables, additional configuration is required to specify which employee changes trigger replication and to define the conditions under which data is pushed to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Data Model Configuration (HRIS & MDF)

To ensure compatibility with SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, key elements of the EC data model should be validated and adjusted if necessary. This includes checking HRIS elements for correctness, making sure mandatory fields are maintained, and aligning field properties such as formatting, field length, and data type. MDF objects must also be reviewed for employee-related data elements so that required data can be successfully replicated. Aligning the data model upfront minimizes replication error and ensures that all data transferred to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud meets the expected structure.

Company Structure and Cost Assignment Alignments

Employee data must be linked to the correct organizational units to enable downstream processes in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, including EHS. It is important to ensure that Legal Entities, Business Units, Departments, and Cost Centers are correctly structured and assigned. In some cases, custom fields may be required to support additional mapping between EC and S/4HANA, depending on the company’s organizational structure. A clear alignment of this data ensures that employees appear in the correct organizational context after replication.

Integration User and Authentication Setup

An integration user with appropriate permissions must be created to allow SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud to retrieve employee data through EC APIs. This includes assigning the required OData API permissions and confirming that the chosen authentication method – basic authentication or certificate-based authentication – is correctly configured. Basic authentication is typically sufficient for testing or demonstration purposes, while certificate-based authentication is recommended for productive environments.

Optional EC Application Settings

In addition to the core configuration steps, EC provides optional settings that can enhance the quality of employee data replicated to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. These include settings such as employee information, and contingent worker data. While not mandatory for the integration, these options can enrich the employee profile in the target system.

3.2 SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Configuration

In addition to setting up SAP SuccessFactors EC, the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud must also be configured to receive employee master data via the SAP Integration Suite. For this purpose, a Communication Arrangement is required to enable secure data exchange between the systems. In this scenario, the predefined Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0001 – Employee Integration is used. Activating and configuring this Communication Arrangement enables the necessary inbound API services, allowing the SAP Integration Suite to push employee data into SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Setup illustration of Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0001

As shown in the illustration above, the Communication Arrangement consists of two key components: an Inbound Communication User and a Communication System.

3.2.1 Communication User

In this integration scenario, an Inbound Communication User was created in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud (e.g. user SF_S4HC). This user was used for Basic Authentication in the Communication Arrangement, and its credentials were securely stored later in the Security Material of SAP Integration Suite to enable a safe connection between the systems.

To create the Inbound Communication User in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, log in to the Fiori Launchpad as an administrator and open the app “Maintain Communication Users”.

Select "Maintain Communication User"

 If no suitable user exists, simply select “New” to create one.

Select New Communication User

Username and password can be freely defined but must be entered later in the Security Material section of the SAP Integration Suite for authentication.

Illustration of our Communication User

These steps align with chapter 5.2 “Integration Credentials Configuration” in the JB1 setup instructions (pages 29–30). For more details on using Certificate-based Authentication instead of Basic Authentication, please refer to the corresponding JB1 guide section.

3.2.2 Communication System

The Communication System defines the technical connection between SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and the external system, in this case SAP Integration Suite. It contains system details such as URLs, authentication methods, and technical identifiers, forming the foundation for all Communication Arrangements that enable secure data exchange. Without a properly configured Communication System, no reliable integration between SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and SAP Integration Suite can take place.

In our setup, the SAP Integration Suite tenant served as the Communication System. If no system exists yet, a new one needs to be created in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. For basic incident management scenarios, this single system is sufficient. However, for additional integrations – such as cost center replication or payroll posting etc. – further configuration might be required (For reference, see chapter 4.1.2 “Create Communication Systems” in the  JB1 setup instructions, pages 30-31).

To create the Communication System, log in to the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Fiori Launchpad as an administrator and open the “Communication Systems” app.

Select "Communication Systems"

 If no suitable entry is available, create a new system by selecting “New”.

Select New Communication System

 Enter a System ID and System Name referring to the Integration Suite tenant and proceed with the set up.

System Setup

After creating the new Communication System entry, additional configuration details must be maintained – including General Data, Technical Data, Log System ID, Business System ID, and the User for Inbound Communication. These parameters define how SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud connects with the external SAP Integration Suite tenant.

For comprehensive configuration guidance, refer to the JB1 setup instructions. In our setup, the Communication System was created with the settings illustrated below.

Illustration of our Communication System (1)Illustration of our Communication System (2)

 3.2.3 Communication Arrangement

The final step in the S/4HANA Public Cloud configuration is to bind the previously created components – the Communication User and the Communication System – within the Communication Arrangement (SAP_COM_0001 – Employee Integration).

Once configured, SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud is ready to receive replicated employee master data from SAP SuccessFactors EC through the SAP Integration Suite. The Communication Arrangement provides the inbound service URLs, which must be stored in the corresponding Integration Flow (iFlow) of the SAP Integration Suite to establish end-to-end communication.

To create the arrangement, log in to the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Fiori Launchpad as an administrator and open the “Communication Arrangements” app.

Select Communication Arrangements

 Then click on “New” to create a new Communication Arrangement.

Create New Communication Arrangement

Choose SAP_COM_0001 as the Communication Scenario.

Assign Communication Scenario

Select Communication Scenario

After that, further setting up configurations needs to be done. Therefore, the before created Communication System will be attached.

Communication Arrangement Setup (Select Communication System))

In our scenario, no additional configuration (e.g. cost center replication, address, or payment information) was required, so these fields remained empty.

Communication Arrangement Setup (Additional Properties))

The Inbound Communication User is automatically populated once the corresponding Communication System is selected. At the same time, the Inbound Service provided the service URL used as the receiver endpoint in the iFlow configuration of the SAP Integration Suite.

Communication Arrangement Setup (Inbound Services)

 3.2.4 Monitoring of Replication Scenarios in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

Accurate and timely replication of employee data from SAP SuccessFactors is essential for Incident Management and other EHS processes. Any replication failure can prevent incidents from being assigned to the correct person or role, impacting compliance and operational safety. SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud provides the Message Dashboard app to monitor replication scenarios. Before using it for the JB1 integration scenario, recipients must be assigned in the “Assign Recipients to Users“ app.

Configuration Steps:

1. Open the "Assign Recipients to Users" app in the SAP Fiori Launchpad.

Select Assign Recipients to Users

 2. Verify that your user is assigned with the following details:

  • Namespace: /WFD
  • Recipient Name: WFD_WORKER_INTEGRATION
  • Message Type: Application Error or Technical Error

Check if Recipients are assigned to User

 3. If your user is not listed, add a new entry using your User ID and the details above.

Add New User and assign New Recipient

Enter User ID

Assign Recipients to User

Once recipients are assigned, the Message Dashboard displays all relevant replication messages – including errors, warnings, and successfully processed records – allowing early detection and resolution of integration issues.

Note: To reprocess messages directly from the Message Board, the user must have the SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR business role assigned. Without this role, reprocessing is not authorized.

Message Dashboard Overview:

Select Message Dashboard

The Message Dashboard provides a consolidated view of all replication messages for the JB1 scenario:

  • The calendar view indicates daily status (green = no errors, red = errors occurred).
  • Messages can be filtered by date range for detailed analysis.
  • The result list summarizes processed messages per interface (e.g., WFD_WORKER/1), including counts of warnings, technical errors, and successful replications.

This monitoring ensures transparency and operational reliability by allowing administrators to quickly identify and resolve replication issues before they impact EHS processes.

Message Dashboard Overview

3.3 Integration Package Implementation in SAP Cloud Integration

3.3.1 Integration Credentials Configuration

In the previous step (chapter 3.2.3), we created Communication Arrangements in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud to enable inbound communication from external systems. These arrangements ensure that SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud can safely receive employee master data from the SAP Integration Suite.

Within the SAP Integration Suite, the Integration Flow (iFlow) must authenticate against two endpoints:

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud – for employee master data via SAP Integration Suite
  • SAP SuccessFactors EC – which triggers the replication process when called by the iFlow

For communication with SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, Basic Authentication was used. The credentials of the Inbound Communication User from SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud must therefore be maintained as Security Material within the SAP Integration Suite. This configuration ensures that the integration flow can authenticate securely when transmitting data between the two systems.

Set up Security Material for Authentication against SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

For communication with SAP SuccessFactors, the iFlow uses OAuth 2.0 SAML Bearer Assertion, which requires creating a Security Material entry with a Key Pair in the SAP Integration Suite. This setup ensures secure authentication whenever the iFlow retrieves data from SAP SuccessFactors.

The highlighted process flow below illustrates where SAP SuccessFactors is triggered by the SAP Integration Suite:

JB1 Process (Maintain Employee Master Data)

For a detailed step-by-step guide on setting up OAuth 2.0 SAML Bearer Assertion and Security Material in SAP Integration Suite, refer to this SAP Community Blog.

3.3.2 Copying Integration Packages

SAP provides preconfigured integration content for scope item JB1 as part of the standard best-practice setup. This allows a straightforward configuration process, since you can simply copy the predefined package into your own workspace. For our scenario, the following integration package was required:

  • SAPSuccessFactorsEmployeeCentralIntegrationwithSAPS4HANAEmployeeData

The package can be found in the Discover section of the SAP Cloud Integration workspace. Once copied, it includes all necessary Integration Flow (iFlow) required for employee master data replication between SAP SuccessFactors EC and SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

In the next step, we will configure these iFlows to establish the data exchange process.

Search for Integration Package in SAP Integration Suite

Copying the Integration Package

 

(These steps correspond to chapter 5.3 “Copying Integration Packages” (pages 55–56) in the JB1 setup instructions.)

3.3.3 Integration Package Configuration

Configuring Employee Master Data Replication Integration Flow (iFlow) for Initial Full Load:

After copying the integration package into your workspace, the first configuration step is the Initial Full Load. This ensures that all relevant employee master data from SAP SuccessFactors EC is replicated into SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud before any delta update occurs.

Why this is important: Accurate and up-to-date employee master data is essential across all EHS use cases, as it ensures that roles, responsibilities, and organizational structures are consistently reflected in safety and compliance processes. This is particularly critical for Incident Management, where incidents must be linked to the correct employees and supervisors. Without a complete initial load, subsequent data updates cannot be processed reliably.

Key Actions:

1. Set the Timer to Run Once: In the iFlow configuration, choose Run Once for the initial execution. This triggers a one-time full replication of all employee master data.

iFlow Settings for Timer

Note: After the initial load is complete, switch the timer to Schedule to Recur for delta replication.

Why is this needed? Because the initial load only runs once. If you leave the timer unchanged, no further updates will be replicated. By switching to a recurring schedule, you enable delta replication, which keeps employee data continuously up to date.

2. Configure Receivers: Next, open the iFlow and click “Configure”. Two recipients must be set up:

iFlow Select Configure

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Receiver: Use the details from Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0001. While Certificate-based Authentication is recommended for productive environments, Basic Authentication can be used for test setups. Enter the service URL of SAP_COM_0001 as the address of the receiver. 

Set up Receiver for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

  • SAP SuccessFactors Receiver: Configure OAuth 2.0 SAML Bearer Assertion for secure API calls. The address can be taken from the JB1 setup instructions (page 57). The Credential Name here is the same as the Security Material created in chapter 3.3.1.

Set up Receiver for SAP SuccessFactors

 3. Adjust Core Parameters

  • Set Initiate_Full_Load = TRUE for the initial run (reset to FALSE afterwards)
  • Define Company Codes and Workforce Type
  • Set the Full_Transmission_Start_Date to include all relevant employee records

Once deployed, the iFlow performs a complete replication of employee master data. This step establishes the foundation for all ongoing delta updates and ensures that EHS processes consistently reference the correct workforce context.

(These steps correspond to chapter 5.4.1 “Configuring Employee Master Data Replication iFlow for Initial Full Load” (pages 56–59) in the JB1 setup instructions.)

Configuring Employee Master Data Replication Integration Flow (iFlow) for Delta Replication:

After the initial full load has established the basic dataset in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the next step is to enable delta replication. This ensures that any changes in SAP SuccessFactors, such as new hires, terminations, or updates to employee information, are continuously synchronized with S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Why this is important: Delta replication plays a key role in keeping employee master data current across all EHS use cases. Accurate and timely workforce is essential not only for Incident Management, but also for other processes like Risk- or Emission-Management, where employee roles and organizational responsibilities drive compliance and reporting accuracy. Without a delta replication, the system would remain static after the initial load, leading to outdated information and potential inconsistencies. By enabling the delta replication, updates are processed incrementally, reducing system load and improving overall efficiency.

Key Checks before Deployment:

To activate delta replication, ensure the following settings are applied (as mentioned in the initial load configuration):

  1. Timer: Set to Schedule to Recur with an appropriate frequency (e.g., every 10 minutes between 00:00 and 24:00).
  2. Parameter: Set Initial_Full_Load = FALSE to switch from full load to incremental updates.

All other configuration steps remain the same as for the initial load.

Result: Once deployed, the iFlow performs incremental updates instead of a full replication, ensuring that SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud always reflects the latest employee master data for EHS and related business processes.

(These steps correspond to chapter 5.4.1 “Configuring Employee Master Data Replication iFlow for Delta Replication” (pages 60 – 61) in the JB1 setup instructions.)

3.3.4 Reset Existing Delta Sync Configuration

In exceptional situations, it may become necessary to reset the delta synchronization configuration. This option is designed to reinitialize the replication process by clearing the stored delta markers, allowing the system to fetch data as if it were the first replication cycle.

When is a reset relevant?

  1. Correction of inconsistencies: If previous delta runs failed or resulted in incomplete updates, a reset ensures that all changes are captured.
  2. Testing and validation: For scenarios where a fresh replication cycle is required without performing a complete system reset.
  3. Troubleshooting: When resolving integration issues that cannot be addressed through standard delta processing.

By resetting the configuration, the system retrieves data from the earliest defined point, ensuring completeness. However, this approach should be applied with caution, as it can lead to significant data volumes being processed again.

How can the Reset be performed?

  1. Open the SAP Cloud Integration Web UI of your SAP Cloud Integration tenant and choose “Monitor” (under Design) from the top-level menu on the left.
  2. In the “Manage Stores” block, choose the “Variables” tile. The available variables are displayed in the Global Data Store.
  3. To reset a replication scenario, delete the corresponding variable(s) from this list by choosing the “Delete” button next to the variable(s). The delete button for each variable is on the right side of the variable table in column “Actions”. The table below specifies the variable name(s) of the variable(s) which needs(s) to be deleted to reset the delta sync configuration for the replication scenario / corresponding Integration Flow (iFlow).

(These steps correspond to chapter 5.5 “Reset Existing Delta Sync Configuration” (pages 69 - 70) in the JB1 setup instructions.)

3.4 End-to-End Monitoring of Employee Master Data Replication

Monitoring is a critical part of ensuring that employee data replication runs smoothly across all systems involved in the JB1 integration scenario. Accurate employee data is the foundation for all EHS processes, as many scenarios – such as incident tracking, risk assessments, and regulatory reporting – depend on reliable workforce information. Inaccurate or incomplete replication can disrupt these processes and impact compliance or operational efficiency.

3.4.1 Monitoring Across Systems

Employee Master Data Replication involves three layers:

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud (Inbound Monitoring): As described in chapter 3.2.4, inbound replication is monitored using the Message Dashboard (AIF Monitoring). This allows administrators to review message statuses and reprocess failed messages if required.
  • SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central (Source Monitoring): In SAP SuccessFactors, replication activity can be monitored using the SFAPI Audit Log, which displays outbound replication calls and related processing information. While this functionality is available, it is not covered in detail here.
  • SAP Integration Suite (Middleware Monitoring): The SAP Integration Suite ensures that data flows correctly between SAP SuccessFactors and SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. Monitoring focuses on the integration flow status, message processing, and error handling within the middle layer.

3.4.2 Monitoring in SAP Integration Suite

SAP Integration Suite provides several tools to track and manage integrations flows:

1. Navigate to Manage Integration Content: Navigate to Monitor > Manage Integration Content to verify that the Integration Flow (iFlow) for employee replication is deployed and running. The status Started indicates that the flow is active.

Navigate to Manage Integration Content

 2. Monitor Message Processing: Under Monitor Message Processing, you can view detailed logs for executed messages.

Navigate to Monitor Message Processing

This view shows whether each message has been successfully processed or if any errors occurred.

Example of successfully completed Message Processing

3. Message Status Overview: The Message Status Overview aggregates statistics across all processed messages, including completed, failed and retried executions. This provides a consolidated view of the integration scenario over a selected timeframe and supports quick identification of patterns or recurring issues.

Message Status Overview

(These steps correspond to chapter 6 “Monitoring of Replication Scenarios” (page 71) in the JB1 setup instructions.)

 

4. Lessons Learned

Implementing JB1 for employee integration in SAP EHS Public Cloud provided several key insights that are even important for similar projects:

1. Employee Integration is Mandatory: Accurate workforce data is the foundation for EHS processes. Without it, Incident Management cannot correctly identify the involved people, assign responsibilities, or ensure compliance.

2. Initial Load is Critical: A successful initial replication establishes the baseline for all subsequent updates. Any errors at this stage can lead to inconsistencies throughout the system.

3. Delta Replication ensures Timelines: Regular updates are essential to reflect organizational changes such as new hires or role adjustments. Without delta replication, the system remains static and operational risks increase.

4. Reset Delta Sync is a Fallback, not a Routine Step: This option is useful for correcting inconsistencies or re-initializing data during testing. However, it should be applied cautiously due to the potential for large data volumes.

5. Monitoring is Essential for Operational Reliability: Continuous monitoring of replication flows prevents disruptions. Tools like AIF monitoring in SAP S/4HANA and Execution Manager in SuccessFactors proved invaluable for early error detection.

6. Authentication Strategy Matters: While Basic Authentication is acceptable for demos or test environments, certificate-based authentication is strongly recommended for production to ensure security standards.

7. Organizational Data Alignment is Key: Mismatches between legal entities and company codes were identified as a common source of replication errors. Early validation avoids downstream issues.

8. Demo vs. Production Considerations: Simplifications used in demos (e.g., Basic Auth) needs to be adapted for production environments to ensure compliance and robustness.

9. Optional Data Can Become a Blocker: Missing or incorrect optional fields, such as bank details, can prevent successful replication. These fields should be validated early in the process.

 

5. Engage with Us

To follow the series, make sure to subscribe to the SAP EHS Public Cloud blog tag.

We welcome your thoughts and feedback in the comments!

Acknowledgements

This blog post series is the result of close collaboration within our EHS implementation team. I would like to express my sincere appreciation to my colleagues, whose expertise, insights, and project experience significantly contributed to the depth and quality of this guide.

A special thank you goes to:

  • @Westphal 
  • @qkroiss 
  • @asutoshmaharana2326 
  • @kanwal_singh
  • @Suraj_Ashray1 

 Their contributions were instrumental in shaping the content of this blog post. I am truly grateful for their collaborations and support.

entry.title: SAP Certification Is Changing: What You Need to Know About the New Format
entry.content:
If you’ve been following SAP’s certification updates, you’ll know things are changing in a big way. The traditional multiple-choice exams are being replaced with a much more practical approach. I recently went through all the latest materials and sessions about the new SAP certification format, especially for SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC), and I want to share what I learned and how you can prepare.

Why Is SAP Changing Its Certification Format?

SAP wants certifications to mean more than just passing a test. The new format is designed to make sure certified professionals can actually do the work required on real SAP projects. Instead of just memorizing theory, you’ll be asked to solve problems and perform tasks that you’d encounter in your day-to-day job. This shift is great news for both candidates and employers. Companies can trust that certified consultants are ready for hands-on work, and candidates can show they’re truly job-ready.

What’s Different About the New Exams?

The biggest change is the move to performance-based assessments. You’ll be asked to complete tasks in a simulated SAP system, or respond to real-world scenarios, sometimes interacting with an AI avatar or submitting a video response. You can use SAP Help Portal, SAP Learning, and even SAP Joule (the AI tool) during the exam, just like you would on a real project. This open-book style makes the exam feel much more like actual work.

You also get to choose how you want to be assessed for some parts: either through an AI role-play or by uploading a video. After you finish, you’ll receive instant feedback, including analytics on your technical depth and communication skills.

Role-Based Certifications and Staying Certified

SAP certifications are now tailored to specific job roles, such as developer, administrator, or architect. This means the exam content is more relevant to what you’ll actually do in your role. Certifications aren’t permanent anymore. You’ll need to complete a “stay-certified” assessment each year to keep your credential active. This helps ensure everyone stays up to date with the latest SAP technology and best practices.

Timeline for the New Format

The rollout starts in November 2025 for selected exams, including SAP BTP Administrator, SAP Build Developer, Solution Architect – SAP BTP, SAP Business Data Cloud, and SAP Generative AI Developer. By 2026, all SAP certifications will use this new practical format.

What Hasn’t Changed?

You’ll still get a digital badge when you pass, and the registration process is the same as before. If you already have a certification, it remains valid, but you’ll need to follow the renewal process to keep it active.

How Should You Prepare?

Focus on building practical SAP skills. Spend time working in SAP simulation environments, and practice explaining SAP solutions clearly and simply. Get comfortable with timed tasks and AI evaluation, and make sure your laptop, internet, webcam, and audio all meet SAP’s technical requirements before exam day.

Spotlight on SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) Certification

The BDC certification is a great example of the new approach. It covers foundational knowledge and practical skills in SAP Business Data Cloud. The assessment includes technical knowledge of BDC, integration with SAP Business Warehouse, SAP Analytics Cloud, SAP Datasphere, and SAP Databricks. To earn the badge, you’ll need to complete the recommended SAP Learning Journey and pass the C_BCBDC exam. Remember to renew your badge every year.

Exam questions breakdown from my attempt:

 

  • Technical Knowledge of BDC (40%)
  • Integration with SAP Business Warehouse (15%)
  • Technical Knowledge of SAP Analytics Cloud (15%)
  • Technical Knowledge of SAP Datasphere (15%)
  • Technical Knowledge of SAP Databricks (15%)

 

Tips for Success

Take your time and use the pause button to think before you answer. Break your responses into clear chunks, and don’t worry about giving too much information, there’s no penalty for being thorough. Read the feedback you get and use it to improve before your next attempt. And don’t rush; you have plenty of time.

Useful Links

Here are some resources that helped me:

  • SAP Certification Overview
  • SAP Certification in the Age of AI
  • SAP BDC Learning Journey
  • SAP Certification BDC

Final Thoughts

SAP’s new certification format is a big step forward. It’s designed to make sure credentials really mean something and that certified professionals are ready for real project work. If you’re preparing for the SAP Business Data Cloud certification, focus on practical skills, clear communication, and continuous learning. The future of SAP certification is here, and it’s all about being ready for the real world.

If you have questions or want to share your experience with the new SAP certification, I’d love to hear from you in the comments.

entry.title: Re: Non-billable items in service order template
entry.content:
Good day @PASEK 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Recurring Services- Missing Maintenance Plan type "Service Order", Service Processing Using a Service Order, Item Categories, Item Categories-Sales

In public cloud, due to clean-core restrictions, Service Order Templates are fixed. Thereby making it a non-editable item category. That also infers that:

  • You cannot add non-billable items to templates,
  • You cannot change item types after the order is created.
  • The Service Contract fully controls the billing relevance and not the Service Order.

My recommendation, therefore, is to keep service contract as the single billing driver, make use of informational Service Orders your maintenance plan generates, add only text or zero-price items in your template and avoid adding any billing relevant configuration at the Service Order level.

The Blog: Recurring Service in S/4HANA Service - Start with an Overview also provides some good insights.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

BR,

Bin

entry.title: Re: Copy of Analytics Stories between Planning Areas in S...
entry.content:
Hello,

 

There isn't an easy way to copy Analytic Stories between Planning Areas, as of IBP 2511. 

Once you copy an Analytic Story, it will automatically copy the data source used (Planning Area) and the setting cannot be changed. What you can try:

1. Run the app job "Import Best Practice Analytics Stories" -> this will generate the standard Stories for your new Planning Area, then you can adjust them. At least it is faster than creating a story from scratch. 

2. Copy the custom Analytic Story -> add the new Planning Area in the "Data Source" tab, then apply a filter that will basically filter out any results from your initial Planning Area (example ABC ID = "D"), in this way the Analytic Story will only display the results of the new PA. (i admit i have not tested this yet). 

 

Regards!

entry.title: Fit2Standard Excellence (1/3): Impactful Preparation and Demo
entry.content:
Co-author:  Oliver-Jens Götz

Rolling out a global S/4HANA core template is never just a technical exercise – it is rather a broader cultural shift for an organization. It’s the pivotal point where local expertise meets a standard global vision. The first two steps of the Fit2Standard approach - Local Units’ Preparation and the System Demo – carry more weight than they seem at the first glance.   

Handled well, these phases set the project on right track, highly reducing rework later in template validation and adoption. Shall they be handled, however, poorly, they create confusion, misalignment across an enterprise and weeks of unnecessary follow-up.

So, how does the right preparation phase look like for a successful Fit2Standard approach?

Local Units’ Preparation: Four Weeks to Shape the Entire Rollout

The rollout begins with the preparation, which is not just an administrative warm-up. It is the point where each unit equips itself to speak with clarity and authority during the entire Fit2Standard implementation.

From the Fit2Standard roadmap (see image above), this phase seems simple and lean embracing onboarding, local information collection, and local team set-up. Nevertheless, in practice, it is much more strategic.

Local teams bring requirements, legal constraints, operational differences, tax rules and real-world transaction examples – all the components that the program team can never know fully in advance. If this information is incomplete or delivered at a later stage, every subsequent Fit2Standard phases will be at risked or slowed down.

A strong preparation embraces the following five factors which have to be carried out in a consistent manner:

Upfront nomination of the correct team: a small, empowered group — a local process owner, local finance/operations SME and an IT contact, — becomes the voice of the unit / entity. This group of people are active decision-makers.

Creation of a solid basis: statutory rules and requirements, sample transactions, org charts, current process documentation, all create a solid basis for later comparison and meaningful usage.

Effective usage of the preparation period:  it provides the local teams to find a shared language with the central team through elevating the time for self-study, intro sessions, training on the S/4 Connect platform.

The System Demo: Bridging Local Reality and the Standard Framework

Following the preparation, comes the moment everyone is waiting for: the first live look at the S/4HANA core template.

In the Fit2Standard timeline, the System Demo is the bridge between preparation and analysis — a shared stage where local expectations meet the standard design.

The Demo Workshop is designed to give the participants insight into the system landscape and infrastructure, end-to-end template processes and transaction flows.

In order to make the demo sessions rewarding for the entire subsequent rollout, it is important to secure a smooth collaboration between the local teams and the project team. Crucial factors of success are:

Realistic, Business-Ready Data

A demo is only credible if it uses meaningful master and transactional data. Realistic data allows users to recognize their business, trust the system behavior, and validate processes accurately.

Clear, Story-Driven Scenarios

A strong demo follows a real end-to-end business scenario—not isolated transactions. A narrative (“day in the life”) helps stakeholders understand how S/4HANA supports and improves their actual workflows.

Fully Prepared and Rehearsed Delivery

The system, roles, configuration, and presenters must be fully prepared. A smooth, well-rehearsed demo builds confidence; a disorganized one generates doubt and resistance.

Capturing Decisions and Actionable Outcomes

The value of a demo lies in its outputs. Clear decisions and assigned actions ensure the demo directly drives design progress instead of becoming a passive show-and-tell.

The demo is the moment when the abstract template becomes tangible for local teams. With proper preparation, teams move from questioning whether the model fits their context to identifying the areas that will require adjustments for their specific case. This mindset shift is the core of Fit2Standard.

Start Strong for a Smooth Fit2Standard Journey

Across many rollouts, one pattern consistently stands out: the results achieved in the final rollout directly depends on the effort put into the preparation phase.
Local Units’ Preparation and the System Demo require relatively moderate effort but yet deliver a significant impact. When local teams commit early, approach it intentionally, the Fit2Standard workstream becomes organized, efficient, and transparent instead of reactive and cumbersome.
These early actions do more than simply initiate the process. They establish the tone, determine the pace, and build the foundation for a successful and scalable global template rollout.

***

Related to the main article: 
Main Article: A Case Study: Mastering a Complex Rollout at a Utilities Enterprise (LINK)

entry.title: Re: Redirect navigation to extended “Manage Central Purch...
entry.content:
We had a similar requirement and we solved this using authorizations. 

Use the same semantic object - action combination as the standard app, but the component points to the extended app in the tile + target mapping of your extended app.  In the role, only the new target mapping is added. 

This should allow you to open the app from other apps using cross app navigation, but will open the extended app since only this is present in the role.

entry.title: Re: How to change the price condition which is overwritte...
entry.content: You must create a variant condition keys using transaction VK30. You must create a condition type with flag 'variant cond' set. Etc. See also F1 help of that flag. You maintain the condition records for your new condition type with the condition key as a key field. See how it is done for VA00.
